questions.text: What is a data model in DBMS, and why is it important?
options: A data model defines how data is structured, stored, and manipulated in a database.
A data model is a physical representation of a file system.
A data model only deals with the security aspects of a database.
A data model is a type of programming language used for querying databases.
questions.correctAnswer: A data model defines how data is structured, stored, and manipulated in a database.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a type of data model in DBMS?
options: Network Model
Hierarchical Model
E-R Model
File Management Model

questions.text: What is the Network Data Model, and how does it represent data?
options: It organizes data using a graph structure with records connected by links, allowing many-to-many relationships.
It represents data in a tree structure with a single parent for each child.
It is used only in relational databases to structure data in tables.
It does not allow relationships between different records.
questions.correctAnswer: It organizes data using a graph structure with records connected by links, allowing many-to-many relationships.

questions.text: What is a major advantage of the Network Data Model?
options: It efficiently represents complex relationships between data using multiple parent-child links.
It is easy to implement and does not require indexing.
It is the simplest model and does not require relationships between entities.
It is a type of file management system.
questions.correctAnswer: It efficiently represents complex relationships between data using multiple parent-child links.

questions.text: What is a disadvantage of the Network Data Model?
options: It is complex to design and requires complex pointers to manage relationships.
It does not support many-to-many relationships.
It cannot handle large amounts of data.
It is not used in modern databases.
questions.correctAnswer: It is complex to design and requires complex pointers to manage relationships.

questions.text: How does the Hierarchical Data Model represent data?
options: It organizes data in a tree-like structure with parent-child relationships.
It uses tables to represent data with relationships between them.
It represents data in a network graph with multiple parent-child relationships.
It uses structured query language (SQL) to define relationships.
questions.correctAnswer: It organizes data in a tree-like structure with parent-child relationships.

questions.text: What is a key disadvantage of the Hierarchical Data Model?
options: It does not support many-to-many relationships and requires data redundancy.
It allows too much flexibility in structuring data.
It does not follow a parent-child structure.
It is the most modern and widely used data model.
questions.correctAnswer: It does not support many-to-many relationships and requires data redundancy.

questions.text: What is an E-R Model in DBMS?
options: It is a conceptual data model that visually represents entities and their relationships.
It is a type of file system for storing data.
It represents data in a tabular form without relationships.
It is used only for hierarchical databases.
questions.correctAnswer: It is a conceptual data model that visually represents entities and their relationships.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly defines an entity set in an E-R Model?
options: A collection of similar entities that share the same attributes.
A group of unrelated data points.
A collection of primary keys in a database.
A data structure used for indexing.
questions.correctAnswer: A collection of similar entities that share the same attributes.

questions.text: What is the difference between a strong entity set and a weak entity set?
options: A strong entity set has a primary key, while a weak entity set does not have a primary key and depends on a strong entity.
Both strong and weak entity sets are independent and have primary keys.
Weak entity sets are used only in hierarchical databases.
Strong entity sets cannot have relationships.
questions.correctAnswer: A strong entity set has a primary key, while a weak entity set does not have a primary key and depends on a strong entity.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a type of key in an entity set?
options: Super Key
Foreign Key
Candidate Key
Primary Key

questions.text: What is a Super Key in DBMS?
options: A set of attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple in a relation.
A single attribute that is always unique.
A key that can never be used in database design.
A key used only in network models.
questions.correctAnswer: A set of attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple in a relation.

questions.text: What is the difference between a Candidate Key and a Primary Key?
options: A candidate key is any minimal set of attributes that can be a primary key, while the primary key is the selected candidate key.
Candidate keys are always foreign keys.
Primary keys are temporary and candidate keys are permanent.
Candidate keys are only used for weak entity sets.
questions.correctAnswer: A candidate key is any minimal set of attributes that can be a primary key, while the primary key is the selected candidate key.

questions.text: What is a Participation Constraint in an E-R Model?
options: It defines whether an entity's participation in a relationship is mandatory or optional.
It ensures that all attributes are unique.
It restricts users from accessing data.
It only applies to hierarchical models.
questions.correctAnswer: It defines whether an entity's participation in a relationship is mandatory or optional.

questions.text: What does an E-R Diagram represent in DBMS?
options: It visually represents entities, relationships, attributes, and constraints.
It is a flowchart for programming languages.
It is used for defining file structures in databases.
It does not provide any visual representation of data.
questions.correctAnswer: It visually represents entities, relationships, attributes, and constraints.
